title: Synthetic Recap
body:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The history books will record a 108-100 victory for the New Jersey Nets over the Boston Celtics. But the true story, the one that will echo through the ages, is the singular, breathtaking masterpiece authored by Nets point guard Sam Cassell.

In a performance for the ages, Cassell detonated for 40 points, a number that fails to capture the sheer dominance of his evening. He was unstoppable, a whirlwind of clutch jumpers and relentless drives that left the Celtics defense grasping at shadows. Every time Boston threatened to close the gap, Cassell had an answer, a cold-blooded bucket to silence the run and steady his team.

While Cassell orchestrated the symphony, he was supported by a powerful duo. Jayson Williams was a force of nature inside, hauling in a monstrous 22 rebounds and adding 19 points for a Herculean double-double. Kendall Gill provided the secondary scoring punch with 21 points of his own, forming a potent one-two punch alongside the incendiary Cassell.

The Celtics, despite the loss, were led by Antoine Walker’s 23 points and a strong 17-point, 14-rebound double-double from rookie Ron Mercer. But on this night, they were merely spectators to a legend being written.

The final score belongs to the Nets, but the night belonged to Sam Cassell. In a game that featured other stellar individual efforts, his 40-point eruption was a supernova, a historic scoring barrage that carved his name into the annals of the franchise and secured a victory his team simply would not be denied.
